choices.text: If depth of invasion is <1 mm surgical margin required is 0.5 cm
If depth of invasion is >2 mm surgical margin required is 3 cm
If depth of invasion is between 1 to 2 mm surgical margin required is 1-2 cm
If there is melanoma in situ no surgical margin is to be excised

questions.text: Which of the following statements about surgical margin during excision of melanoma is true ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) If the depth of invasion of melanoma is 1-2 mm the surgical margin required is 1-2 cm

choices.text: Collagen and elastin lines in stab wound
Point of maximum tension in a fracture

questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Kraissl's lines are a set of anatomical skin lines. They differ from Langer's lines in that unlike Langer's lines, which are defined in term of collagen orientation, Kraissl's lines are the lines of maximum skin tension Blaschko's lines, also called the lines of Blaschko, named after Alfred Blaschko, are lines of normal cell development in the skin. These lines are invisible under normal conditions. They become apparent when some diseases of the skin or mucosa manifest themselves according to these patterns. They follow a "V" shape over the back, "S" shaped whirls over the chest and sides, and wavy shapes on the head. The lines are believed to trace the migration of embryonic cells.

questions.text: A patient developed a nodular lesion with central telangiectasia over the nose . What is the diagnosis of this patient ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Basal-cell carcinoma (BCC), also known as basal-cell cancer, is the most common type of skin cancer.It often appears as a painless raised area of skin, which may be shiny with small blood vessels running over it; or it may present as a raised area with ulceration. Basal-cell cancer grows slowly and can damage the tissue around it but is unlikely to spread to distant areas or to result in death. Option D. Keratoacanthoma (KA) is a common low-grade (unlikely to metastasize or invade) rapidly-growing skin tumour that is believed to originate from the hair follicle (pilosebaceous unit) and can resemble squamous cell carcinoma. The defining characteristic of a keratoacanthoma is that it is dome-shaped, symmetrical, surrounded by a smooth wall of inflamed skin, and capped with keratin scales and debris. It grows rapidly, reaching a large size within days or weeks, and if untreated for months will almost always starve itself of nourishment, necrose (die), slough, and heal with scarring.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis based on the following image ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Sebaceous cyst is a non-fluctuant, compressible mass and has a central, dark comedone opening (punctum) . Cysts are usually asymptomatic, can be found anywhere but are commonly found on the face, neck, chest, upper back, scrotum, and genitals. If cyst ruptures it may closely resemble a furuncle with tenderness to palpation, erythema, and swelling. A foul-smelling yellowish cheese-like material discharged from the skin may be described.

questions.text: Sebaceous cysts do not occur on ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Sebaceous cysts are usually asymptomatic and can be found on regions which contain hair follicles like scalp, face , scrotum , genitals ,chest , upper back . They are not present on palms and soles

questions.text: Durcum disease is commonest in the ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Durcum Disease : A rare condition characterized by multiple, painful lipomas. These lipomas mainly occur on the back, trunk,upper arms and upper legs. Mostly occur between 35–50 years, more common in women Clinical Features •Multiple Lipomas And Neuropathic Pain Are the cardinal symptoms Treatment •Treatment is usually targeted towards pain relief rather than lipoma removal.

questions.text: Hidradenitis suppurativa is found to occur in ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) commonly occurs in axilla. The condition tends to start with a firm pea-sized lesion that develops in one place. This will either disappear or rupture and ooze pus after a few hours or days. New lumps will then often develop in an area nearby. If these aren't controlled with medication, larger lumps may develop and spread. Narrow channels called sinus tracts also form under the skin that break out on the surface and leak pus.

questions.text: Margins Of Squamous Cell Carcinoma Is:

choices.text: A type of basal cell carcinoma
Self healing nodular lesion with central ulceration

questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Keratoacanthoma Is self healing nodular lesion with central ulceration More common in men, usually found on the face of 50–70 years old. Lesions can grow to 1–3 cm over 6 weeks and typically resolve spontaneously over the subsequent 6 months Classically a cup-shaped growth that exhibits symmetry about its middle. Central Crater Is filled with a plug of keratin. Unclear Etiology(may be caused by HPV infecting a hair follicle) Associated with smoking and chemical carcinogen exposure. Treatment :- Removal Of Central Keratin Plug May speed resolution. Excision Is recommended for persistent lesions

questions.text: A 43-years-old woman is diagnosed with a condition that causes excruciating pain near her nose and mouth. The involved nerve innervates which of the following branchial arches?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The clinical history suggests trigeminal neuralgia, which is characterized by extreme pain along the distributions of the maxillary and mandibular subdivisions of the fifth cranial nerve. The trigeminal nerve innervates the first branchial arch.

questions.text: ABCDE principle is used for which malignancy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) ABCDE principle is used for Malignant melanoma,It stands for:- Asymmetry Border → Irregular Colour → Variegated Diameter >6mm Evolving → any change in size, shape, colour Any E + any of A to D → indication of BIOPSY

questions.text: Identify the disorder seen in the image
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-This is a Classical image of Plexiform neurofibroma,involving the trigeminal nerve area. Option B-Lipoma is the most common benign tumour.It is soft and well circumscribed tumour. Option C-Sarcoma can have a retroperitoneal/musculoskeletal origin. Option D-Schwanomma occurs in CN VIII territory.It can occur at cerebellopontine angle.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with a non-healing ulcer on the right cheek that has been slowly enlarging over the past six months. On examination, the lesion is pearly with rolled edges and visible telangiectasia as shown below. There is no regional lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Basal cell carcinoma 1. Key Features in the Clinical Scenario: o Non-healing ulcer: Persistent lesions are concerning for malignancy. o Pearly appearance with rolled edges: This is a classic description of basal cell carcinoma (BCC). o Telangiectasia: Another hallmark finding of BCC. o Slow growth over 6 months: BCC is typically slow-growing and rarely metastasizes. 2. Differential Diagnoses: o Malignant melanoma: Usually presents as an asymmetrical pigmented lesion with irregular borders, color variation, and rapid growth. o Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC): May present as a non-healing ulcer but usually with a more aggressive appearance, crusting, or overlying hyperkeratosis. SCC is often seen on sun-exposed areas. o Seborrheic keratosis: A benign lesion with a "stuck-on" appearance, not ulcerative. o Actinic keratosis: A precursor to SCC that presents as a scaly, erythematous macule or patch, not a rolled-edged ulcer. 3. Importance of Diagnosis: o BCC is the most common skin cancer, especially in older adults with significant sun exposure. o It has a very low metastatic potential but can cause local destruction if untreated. 4. Management: o Confirm diagnosis with skin biopsy. o Treatment options include surgical excision, Mohs micrographic surgery, or less commonly, cryotherapy or topical therapies for superficial BCC.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a darkly pigmented lesion on her left forearm. She reports noticing an increase in size and color variation over the past 3 months. On examination, the lesion is asymmetrical, has irregular borders, varies in color, and is approximately 1.5 cm in diameter. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Excisional biopsy with 2-mm margins 1. Key Clinical Features: o Asymmetry, irregular borders, color variation, and size >6 mm are suggestive of malignant melanoma (ABCDE criteria). o Any rapidly changing pigmented lesion warrants immediate evaluation. 2. Management: o An excisional biopsy with narrow margins is the gold standard for diagnosing melanoma. It provides a full-thickness specimen for histopathological evaluation. o A shave biopsy (C) is not appropriate as it may not provide adequate depth for staging. o Cryotherapy (D) are not used for melanoma.

questions.text: A 70-year-old farmer presents with a scaly, erythematous lesion on his lower lip. He reports that the lesion has been present for a year and occasionally bleeds. Examination reveals a firm, scaly plaque with an erythematous base. There is no regional lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Squamous cell carcinoma 1. Key Clinical Features: o A firm, scaly plaque that occasionally bleeds is characteristic of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). o SCC is more common on sun-exposed areas, especially in individuals with extensive UV exposure (e.g., farmers). o The lower lip is a common site for SCC, often related to chronic sun exposure. 2. Differential Diagnoses: o Basal cell carcinoma (A): Typically presents as a pearly papule with rolled edges and telangiectasia. o Actinic keratosis (C): Precursor lesion to SCC but smaller and less invasive. o Malignant melanoma (D): Presents as a pigmented lesion with ABCDE criteria. 3. Management: o Biopsy to confirm diagnosis. o Wide local excision or Mohs micrographic surgery is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man has a lesion on his scalp that has been increasing in size for the past year. Examination shows a dome-shaped, rapidly growing nodule with central keratin-filled crater. The lesion appears well-circumscribed, and there is no lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Keratoacanthoma 1. Key Clinical Features: o Dome-shaped nodule with a central keratin-filled crater is a classic description of keratoacanthoma (KA). o KA is a rapidly growing lesion that may resemble SCC but often regresses spontaneously. 2. Differential Diagnoses: o Squamous cell carcinoma (B): Can look similar but tends to grow slower and does not spontaneously regress. o Basal cell carcinoma (C): Pearly, telangiectatic lesions without central keratin. o Actinic keratosis (D): Premalignant, presenting as flat, scaly lesions. 3. Management: o While KA can regress, excision is typically recommended to differentiate it from SCC and prevent local tissue destruction.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a lesion on his forehead that has been increasing in size over the past year. On examination, there is a non-healing, ulcerated lesion with rolled edges and visible telangiectasia. There is no evidence of metastasis. What is the most appropriate treatment for this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Mohs micrographic surgery 1. Key Features in the Scenario: o The lesion is described as non-healing, ulcerated with rolled edges and telangiectasia, characteristic of basal cell carcinoma (BCC). 2. Management: o Mohs micrographic surgery is the treatment of choice for high-risk BCC, especially on the face or cosmetically sensitive areas, as it allows maximal tissue preservation while ensuring clear margins. o Cryotherapy (A) and topical imiquimod (B) are used for superficial BCC but are not suitable for invasive lesions. o Wide excision (D) is an option but is not as tissue-sparing as Mohs surgery.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman notices a new pigmented lesion on her back. It is asymmetrical, has irregular borders, exhibits multiple colors (brown, black, and red), and measures 1.2 cm in diameter. She has a family history of melanoma. Which of the following genetic mutations is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) BRAF 1. Key Features in the Scenario: o The lesion fits the ABCDE criteria for melanoma (Asymmetry, Border irregularity, Color variation, Diameter >6 mm, and Evolution). o Family history further increases suspicion of melanoma. 2. Genetics of Melanoma: o The BRAF mutation, particularly BRAF V600E, is commonly associated with melanoma. o Other mutations, such as TP53 (C) and PTEN (D), are seen in various cancers but less frequently in melanoma. o BRCA1 (A) is linked to breast and ovarian cancer.
